GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 15, 2024
Holly Anderton
ST. JOHN'S HOME RESIDENTIAL
2355 KNAPP ST NE,
GRAND RAPIDS, MI, 49505-4411
Re: License #: CI410305582
Dear Ms. Anderton:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 02/06/2024. The renewal inspection has determined substantial compliance with
applicable licensing statutes and rules. Your license is renewed, and you will be receiving
the license in the mail. It is valid only at your present address and is nontransferable. If
you move, please notify us at least 30 days in advance.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• During the time of the onsite audit there was no technical assistance provided.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:

• During the time of the onsite audit there was no consultation provided.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 1 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. This was within investigation report 2024C00008891SI dated 11/06/2023
which found the facility in non-compliance of a staff member shoving a youth when
a youth was escalated. A corrective action plan dated 01/02/2024 was approved
that included the staff member involved being terminated from employment and
implementation of training and burnout check ins with supervisors.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
review period begins September 18, 2023, until current. The agency was granted a
1st Provisional License on September 18, 2023, due to Special Investigation
Report 20223C0000595. Prior to the Provisional License being granted, there was
two investigations still pending that ended up resulting in a CAP which were due to
supervision concerns, emergency restraint techniques not being utilized
appropriately, and the documentation of the restraint was not completed timely.
Both CAPS were approved post the 1st Provisional License and action steps have
been implemented. One CAP was the result of special investigation
2023C0000753SI resulting in findings for supervision concerns due to a third shift
staff member sleeping. The facility implemented a CAP which terminated that staff
member who was sleeping, having increase live stream video reviews during third
shift and a new position of a third shift team lead who would be a staff out of ratio
to help support staff during third shift. The other CAP was the result of special
investigation 2023C00007791 which resulted in findings as a staff member was
not keeping eyes on a youth when they exited the home without permission, going
into a restraint post a youth having escalating behaviors and documentation of the
restraint not being completed timely. Since this CAP implementation there has
been scenario-based trainings on supervision requirements, increase in staff
coaching within increased supervision support, and re-training of the restraint
model. All corrective action plans have been implemented and all action steps
have been met in the required timeframes.
Since the start of the 1st Provisional License, September 18, 2023, there has been
7 total investigations with 2 investigations resulting in compliance, 1 resulting in a
CAP, and 4 investigations are still pending. The one investigation resulting in a
CAP was report 2024C0000899SI as mentioned above. There are still 4 pending
investigations at this time, which involved the following: Investigation
2024C000088SI involves an incident that allegedly occurred on 9/12/2024, before
the facility enter provisional status, of a staff member potentially having an
inappropriate relationship with a youth. Investigation 2024C0000043SI involves a
complaint from a youth that lived in the facility in 2009-2011 and the staff involved

in this investigation are no longer employed at the facility. Investigation
2024C0001118 involves concerns of a staff member potentially providing a youth
nicotine off campus. There is also a potential finding of a staff member being
aware of the situation and not reporting it until a few days later due to fear of that
staff member in question. Investigation 2024C00001122SI involves concern of
staff supervision during an off campus outing which allowed two youth to have
sexual intercourse. The pending investigations are either about incidents prior to
the first provisional or a situation that occurred off campus grounds which is not
similar to the concerns that led the facility into first provisional status.
The facility was placed on a 1st Provisional License due to concerns of staff not
having adequate supervision which has led to youth being in unsafe situation. The
facility has implemented all of their CAPS which involve supervisors completing
video review of shifts, quality assurance staff completing video review for every
incident report and pulling random time video reviews, having in real time video
review occurring, and having instant feedback with staff both positive and negative
in regard to findings from the video review. The facility also completed scenario-
based trainings to have staff engaged about importance of supervision guidelines
and child safety. The facility implemented a third shift lead worker role which
allows a veteran third shift staff member provide real time training and feedback to
third shift staff. This role also allows for a third shift worker to be out of ratio so that
support can be provided. The facility implemented increased supervision with the
supervisors and direct care staff. The supervisors also complete a weekly tasks
checklist to provide to their supervisors of the individual supervision they have
completed, reviewing checklist completions at the homes, reviewing video footage,
reviewing specifically third shift video footage, and also completing reviews of daily
observation records. Majority of the facilities special investigation were reported to
state licensing by the facility staff themselves. They took appropriate steps when
an investigation occurred by putting any at risk staff on leave immediately and
terminating when found staff were not completing their duties appropriately. The
facility is working on proactive solutions including changing their hiring process to
include specific questions for potential candidates of scenario basis. The facility
has had a change in leadership with downsizing and letting go their program
manager. The previous program manager did not have experience with the child
caring institution rules which posed barriers within his role. The Chief Administrator
now directly oversees the four supervisors. The Chief Administrator and home
supervisors will be involved in hiring the direct care staff. They are implementing
the Safety Systems: Abuse Prevention screening into their hiring process.
Since being under a First Provisional License the facility completed weekly
scheduled onsite meetings with this consultant and complied with monthly
unannounced visits. The weekly scheduled onsite meeting occurred at the start of
the provisional September 19, 2024, and lasted until January 16, 2024. During
these weekly meetings, DCWL met with RCTAU and leadership at the facility.
These meetings consisted of review of CAPS and in the moment consultation or
technical assistance that may be needed. Safety checks were also completed with

all the youth who reported feeling safe at the facility and noted increased
supervision was occurring with staff.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility’s
budget and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported, "The provisional CAP has been successful in
achieving proper supervision of youth and ensuring staff issues are managed in a
more timely manner." The Chief Administrator notes that the video review process
that was noted in majority of the facility's CAPS has greatly improved real time
feedback to staff so they can remedy problems quickly. It has also provided an
opportunity to provide positive feedback to staff, to reinforce positive behaviors.
The Chief Administrator plans to have continued video review variable home/shifts
to ensure staff compliance with policy and procedure. The goal would be to have
the Quality Improvement Specialist review at least one time per month each direct
care staff member on shift. The facility also plans to incorporate the Safety
Systems: Abuse Prevention Screen and hiring process to improve in hiring staff of
high integrity.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff have reported they feel very supported by leadership and feel that when they
have a concern or question their voice is heard. Staff reported since going on a
first provisional, there has been a shift in culture of working as a team and putting
child safety first. The staff reported they have enjoyed the scenario-based trainings
as it more applicable to their jobs.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or concerns
were raised. The youth reported staff have been more on top of them with their
room checks and complete mental health checks with the youth. The youth
reported they feel safe and have a positive relationship with the staff. They all
reported whenever they have a concern and they express it to staff, the staff take it
seriously and look into the situation.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on February 6, 2024.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
02/20/2024
